activity.bestPlaces: Flowers Market (Also Princep Ghat, Millennium Park)
activity.description: While the flower market is vibrant in the morning, sunset views are best at riverside spots. This activity description is more suited to a place like Princep Ghat or Millennium Park, where you can watch the sun set over the Hooghly River.
A classic, old-world experience of riding in a horse-drawn carriage around the sprawling grounds of the Victoria Memorial.
essentials: Camera, comfortable clothes, and money for the ride.

activity.description: A sprawling urban park with a variety of themed gardens and recreational activities, including a "Seven Wonders of the World" replica section, boating, and cycling.
essentials: Wear comfortable shoes, carry a water bottle, and a hat or sunglasses.

activity.description: A bustling hub of restaurants, pubs, and shops. It's famous for its vibrant nightlife and diverse culinary scene.
essentials: Dress code for specific clubs, money for dining and entertainment.

activity.bestPlaces: Anywhere as you choice (Various routes, e.g., Shyambazar to Esplanade)
activity.description: Experience the last operational tram network in India. A slow, nostalgic journey through the city's bustling streets, offering a unique perspective of Kolkata's daily life.
essentials: Check the route map, carry a water bottle, and have a camera ready.

activity.bestPlaces: Princep Ghat (Also Millennium Park, Howrah Ghat)
activity.description: A ferry ride on the Hooghly River provides a unique vantage point to see the city. You can enjoy stunning views of the Howrah Bridge and Vidyasagar Setu.
essentials: A small amount of cash for the ticket, and a camera.

activity.description: One of the oldest and largest cricket stadiums in India. The atmosphere during a match, especially an international one, is electrifying.
essentials: Check for match schedules and book tickets in advance. Carry essentials like a hat, sunglasses, and water.

activity.bestPlaces: Aqua - The Park (Also other venues on Park Street)
activity.description: A popular poolside lounge bar known for its luxurious and vibrant ambiance. A great place to relax by the pool, enjoy drinks, and socialize.
essentials: Smart casual or upscale attire may be required.

cityinfo.climateInfo: Kolkata has hot and humid summers, heavy rains during the monsoon from June to September, and mild, pleasant winters that rarely get too cold.
cityinfo.cityHistory: Kolkata, or Calcutta, was a colonial city. The British East India Company developed Calcutta as a village by establishing an artificial riverine port in the 18th century CE. Kolkata was the capital of the British India until 1911, when the capital was relocated to Delhi. Kolkata grew rapidly in the 19th century to become the second most important city of the British Empire after London and was declared as the financial (commercial) capital of the British India. This was accompanied by the fall of a culture that fused Indian philosophies with European tradition. Kolkata is also noted for its revolutionary history, ranging from the Indian to the leftist Naxalite and trade-union movements. Labelled the "Cultural Capital of India", "The City of Britain", "The City of Revolutionaries", and the "City of Joy", Kolkata has also been home to prominent statesmen, scientists, philosophers and literary personalities. Problems related to rapid urbanization started to plague Kolkata from the 1930s and the city remains an example of the urbanization challenges of the developing nations.

hiddengem.description: Chandannagar, also known as Chandernagor, is a city in West Bengal’s Hooghly district, renowned for its distinctive French colonial legacy. The city showcases this heritage through its well-preserved colonial architecture, the iconic Strand, landmarks like the Dupleix House Museum, and remnants of its French past. Once a French colony until 1951, Chandannagar continues to embody a unique fusion of Bengali traditions and French cultural influence.
hiddengem.essential: Wear comfortable shoes;Carry an umbrella in summers;Best visited in daytime;Follow local rules
hiddengem.story: Chandannagar emerged during the colonial era, as evidenced by the absence of its mention in medieval Bengali texts. Historians believe the French established the town by merging several smaller localities in the region. In 1688, Boureau-Deslandes, the first Director of the French East India Company, paid 40,000 coins to the Mughal subahdar to secure rights over the area and set up a trading factory. The first Frenchman to acquire land here was Du Plessis, who purchased 13 arpents at Boro Kishanganj. Later, in 1730, Joseph François Dupleix became governor, under whose administration more than two thousand brick houses were built, and the town developed into a hub of thriving maritime trade.

hiddengem.description: Chinsurah, located on the banks of the Hooghly River about 35 km north of Kolkata, is home to the oldest Armenian church in India as well as several historic Hindu temples. The town is well connected by rail, with three stations on the Howrah line—Chinsurah (CNS), Hooghly (HGY), and Bandel Junction (BDC)—alongside Hooghly Ghat (HYG) on the Sealdah line. Local transportation is primarily served by buses, autos, rickshaws, and totos.
hiddengem.essential: Wear comfortable shoes;Carry an umbrella in summers;Best visited in daytime;Follow local rules
hiddengem.story: The Portuguese established the town of Ugulim in 1579, though the region’s heritage stretches back thousands of years to the powerful kingdom of Bhurshut. As a trading port, the town prospered and saw the construction of several religious sites, including a Christian church dedicated to a statue of Mary brought by the Portuguese. In 1629, political turmoil led the Mughal governor of Bengal to expel the Portuguese. During their retreat, the statue was lost in the river but was later recovered by locals on the riverbank. Following the expulsion, the town was designated the royal port of Bengal, with all public offices and records relocated there. In 1640, the East India Company set up a factory in Hugli, marking its first settlement in Lower Bengal.

hiddengem.description: Diamond Harbour, formerly known as Hajipur, is a historic riverside town in West Bengal situated on the banks of the Hugli River. It developed as an important center for agricultural trade and port activities, while also gaining popularity as a tourist destination for its pleasant climate, scenic river views, and proximity to places like Gangasagar. The British gave it the name Diamond Harbour, reflecting its significance as a hub for both river and sea shipping.
hiddengem.essential: Wear comfortable shoes;Carry an umbrella in summers;Best visited in daytime;Follow local rules;Refrain from the water body if water level is high
hiddengem.story: Diamond Harbour, originally called Hajipur due to its location along the Hajipur creek, was renamed by the British, who used it as a base for both river and sea shipping. The area has been known since the 16th and 17th centuries for the presence of Portuguese river pirates, locally referred to as *harmad*. A fort known as Chingrikhali Kella, believed to have been built by these pirates in the 1600s, still stands today in a dilapidated state.

hiddengem.description: Bansberia, once a principal city of the ancient Saptagram region, holds significant historical importance. Located in today’s Hooghly district of West Bengal, it is home to the Zafar Khan Ghazi Mosque and Dargah at Tribeni, which are regarded as some of the earliest surviving Muslim monuments in Bengal. An inscription dates the mosque to 698 AH (1298 AD), highlighting its deep-rooted heritage.
hiddengem.essential: Wear modest clothing;Cover your head in the mosque;Wear comfortable shoes;Carry an umbrella in summers;Best visited in daytime;Follow local rules
hiddengem.story: The Zafar Khan Ghazi Mosque and Dargah at Tribeni in Hooghly district, West Bengal, are among the earliest surviving Muslim monuments in Bengal. Built during the initial phase of the Muslim conquest of the region, the mosque is an oblong structure measuring 23.38 by 10.53 metres (76.7 by 34.5 ft) externally. It represents the earliest known example of the brick-and-stone construction style introduced by the Muslims in Bengal, replacing the traditional Hindu technique of stacking rectangular cut stones without mortar.

nearbyspot.description: Situated on the west bank of the Hooghly River, Serampore was a pre-colonial settlement that became part of Danish India under the name Frederiknagore from 1755 to 1845. In 1755, the Danish Asiatic Company returned to Bengal with the intention of trading in silk, cotton, spices, indigo—the natural blue dye—and saltpetre, an essential ingredient in black powder. The company negotiated a fresh agreement with the Mughal governor of Bengal, who granted them permission to establish a trading post in Serampore, provided they paid taxes on their trade and upheld law and order in the area.Today, Serampore has grown into a modern commercial town with bustling markets, shops, and restaurants. The historic centre built by the Danes still houses public offices and courthouses, while also serving as the town’s main recreational hub. Restored colonial-era buildings draw both Indian and international visitors, adding to its cultural appeal. The town is also renowned for Serampore College, founded by British missionaries during the period of Danish rule.
nearbyspot.essential: Carry water and sun protection, and wear comfortable walking shoes to ensure a pleasant visit, as exploring the area involves a fair amount of walking. Local guides can greatly enhance the experience by providing valuable insights into the history and significance of the monument
nearbyspot.story: Serampore, a city with centuries of history, has undergone remarkable transformations over time. It first saw the arrival of the Danes, who established a settlement in 1755 after the Danish East India Company secured a parwana (royal decree) from Nawab Alivardi Khan through its representative from Tranquebar. This marked the beginning of Danish colonial presence in Bengal. The settlement later came under British control in 1845, ushering in a phase of rapid industrialization with the development of railways, factories, and related infrastructure. These changes ultimately transformed Serampore into a thriving industrial hub.

nearbyspot.description: Barrackpore is famous for its historical significance as the oldest British cantonment in India and for being the site of early revolts against British rule, particularly the 1857 Sepoy Mutiny triggered by Mangal Pandey. Today, it is known for landmarks such as Mangal Pandey Park and the Gandhi Museum, which commemorates Mahatma Gandhi's ashes being immersed there
nearbyspot.essential: Carry water and sun protection, and wear comfortable walking shoes to ensure a pleasant visit, as exploring the area involves a fair amount of walking. Local guides can greatly enhance the experience by providing valuable insights into the history and significance of the monument
nearbyspot.story: The first British barracks or cantonment in India was established in Barrackpore in 1772. Following the transfer of power to the British Crown, the expansive Government House and Government Estate were constructed there, serving as a suburban residence for the Viceroy, located about 20 kilometres (12 miles) from Calcutta.Barrackpore was also the site of two significant uprisings against British authority in the 19th century. The first was the Barrackpore Mutiny of 1824, led by sepoy Bindee Tiwary. Later, in 1857, the town witnessed an incident often regarded as a spark for the Indian Rebellion of 1857. Here, sepoy Mangal Pandey attacked his British officer and was court-martialed. In response, his regiment was disbanded—an act that deeply angered many sepoys and is believed to have intensified the resentment that ultimately fuelled the rebellion.

nearbyspot.address: Belur Math Rd, Belur Math, Howrah, West Bengal (711202)
nearbyspot.description: It is located in Belur, West Bengal, India on the west bank of Hooghly River.Belur Math was established in January 1897, by Swami Vivekananda who was the disciple of Sri Ramakrishna.The temple is the heart of the Ramakrishna movement. It is notable for its architecture that fuses Hindu, Islamic, Buddhist, and Christian art and motifs as a symbol of unity of all religions.The temple is considered a prime example of the importance of "material dimension" of religion.
nearbyspot.essential: Modest dress required; remove shoes at temples; avoid alcohol and non-vegetarian food; use designated ghats for bathing; keep the confluence clean; follow priestly or local guidance during rituals.
nearbyspot.story: Belur Math is the headquarters of the Ramakrishna Math and Ramakrishna Mission, founded by Swami Vivekananda, the chief disciple of Ramakrishna Paramahamsa.Ramakrishna Math and Ramakrishna Mission are worldwide, non-political, non-sectarian spiritual organizations which have been engaged in various forms of humanitarian, social service activities for more than a century. Inspired by the ideals of renunciation and service, the monks and lay devotees of the Math and Mission serve millions of men, women and children, without any distinction of caste, religion or race, because they see the living God in them.

nearbyspot.address: Mandir Rd, Tarkeshwar, Bhanjipur, West Bengal (712410)
nearbyspot.description: The temple derives its name from the Tarakeswara form of Lord Mahadev. It is traditionally believed to have been constructed by the Malla Raja of Bishnupur. Built in the Atchala style of Bengal temple architecture, the Taraknath Mandir features a sanctum crowned with four sloping roofs, a natmandir (prayer hall) at the front, and extended galleries to accommodate large gatherings of devotees.To the north of the temple lies Dudhpukur, a sacred pond believed to grant the wishes of those who take a ritual dip in its waters. The temple is also regarded by some as one of the Jyotirlinga shrines of Lord Mahadev. Pilgrims throng to Taraknath Temple throughout the year, with Mondays being especially significant for worship.
nearbyspot.essential: Modest dress required; remove shoes at temples; avoid alcohol and non-vegetarian food; keep the confluence clean; follow priestly or local guidance during rituals.
nearbyspot.story: Tarakeswar is a renowned pilgrimage town and municipality in the Hooghly district of West Bengal, India. Popularly known as “Baba Dham” or “The City of Shiva”, it is considered one of the most important holy destinations in West Bengal and across India.At the heart of the town stands the Taraknath Temple, a famous Hindu shrine dedicated to Lord Shiva. The temple houses a Shayambhu linga (self-manifested symbol) of Shiva and is believed to have been built in 1729 CE by Raja Bharamalla Rao.

nearbyspot.description: Located about 3 km from Hooghly Railway Station, the Basilica of the Holy Rosary—popularly known as Bandel Church—is one of the oldest churches in West Bengal and a major attraction in Hooghly.Originally founded in 1599, the church is dedicated to Nossa Senhora do Rosário (Our Lady of the Rosary) and commemorates the Portuguese settlement in Bengal. It belongs to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Calcutta and is one of the 23 Basilica Churches in India. The present structure, along with the adjoining monastery, was built in 1660 by Gomez de Soto after the original church was destroyed by the Mughal army under Emperor Shah Jahan. A relic of the earlier building—the keystone inscribed with the date 1599—still survives and can be seen on the eastern gate of the monastery.
nearbyspot.essential: Modest dress required; avoid eating inside the premises ;  keep the church clean; follow priestly or local guidance during rituals.
nearbyspot.story: The Bandel Church, formally known as the Basilica of the Holy Rosary, is among the oldest Christian churches in West Bengal, India. Established in 1599, it was built as a memorial to the Portuguese settlement in Bengal and is dedicated to Nossa Senhora do Rosário (Our Lady of the Rosary). Today, it functions both as a parish church under the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Calcutta and as one of the most significant historical churches in West Bengal and India.

nearbyspot.address: Imambara Rd, near D.M Banglw, Chowk Bazar, Olaichanditala, Chinsurah, West Bengal (712103)
nearbyspot.description: The Hooghly Imambara is a Twelver Shia congregation hall and mosque located in Hooghly, West Bengal, India. Its construction was initiated by Muhammad Mohsin in 1841 and completed in 1861. The two-storied structure features a prominent clock tower above the entrance gate and is renowned for its intricate architectural details. Verses from the Quran are engraved on its walls, while the interiors are adorned with marble, candles, and hanging lanterns, adding to its grandeur.
nearbyspot.essential: Modest dress required; avoid alcohol ;  keep the confluence clean; follow priestly or local guidance during rituals.
nearbyspot.story: The Hooghly Imambara is particularly renowned for its grand clock, positioned between the twin towers that rise above the main entrance. Each tower stands at a height of about 46 metres (150 ft) and contains 152 steps leading to the top.Visitors from Kolkata usually travel by train to Naihati Junction, then take a Bandel local train to Hooghly Ghat station. From there, the Imambara is within walking distance, though rickshaws and auto-rickshaws are also available to ferry visitors directly to the site.

place.address: Dakshineswar, Kolkata, West Bengal 700035
place.description: This is a big, beautiful temple right by the river. It's dedicated to Goddess Kali, but what makes it special is its connection to Sri Ramakrishna, a famous saint who lived here. It feels incredibly peaceful, especially when you see the small Shiva temples lined up along the riverbank.
place.essential: This is a spiritual place, so a heads-up: you'll want to dress a bit more conservatively. Also, wear shoes you can slip off easily, because you'll have to take them off. It gets super busy on weekends, so go early if you want to avoid the big crowds!
place.story: Built by Rani Rashmoni in 1855 after a dream, this temple is a masterpiece of Navaratna architecture. It's where Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa achieved spiritual enlightenment and where he taught his disciples, including Swami Vivekananda.

place.address: Anami Sangha, Kalighat, Kolkata, West Bengal 700026
place.description: If you're looking for a powerful spiritual experience, this is the place. It’s one of the oldest and most important Kali temples in India. The atmosphere is super intense and full of devotion. You'll see a lot of people praying and making offerings here.
place.essential: Okay, this place is intense in the best way. It's a major pilgrimage site, so it's often crowded. Just be smart with your wallet and don't get sidetracked by anyone trying to sell you a "special" tour. It's all part of the experience, but it's best to stick to the main path.
place.story: A sacred "Shakti Peeth" where, according to mythology, the toes of Sati fell. The current temple was built in the 19th century, but the site has been a place of worship for centuries. It's a vibrant hub of devotion and a powerful symbol of the goddess Kali.

place.address: Raja Nabakrishna St, Raja Nabakrishna Street, Sovabazar, Kolkata, West Bengal 700005
place.description: This is a grand old mansion that feels like a trip back in time. It was built by a famous Bengali noble, and it's a perfect example of the city's old wealth and heritage. The best time to visit is during Durga Puja—the celebrations are legendary!
place.essential: The best time to see this place is during the Durga Puja festival; the whole mansion just comes alive. Otherwise, remember that it's a private home, so you might want to call ahead to see if they're open to visitors.
place.story: The palace of Raja Nabakrishna Deb, a powerful zamindar and a key figure in 18th-century Bengal. It's famous for hosting Lord Clive and for its grand Durga Puja celebrations, which are one of the oldest and most traditional in the city.

place.address: Raja Katra, Machuabazar, Kolkata, West Bengal 700007
place.description: Prepare to be amazed by this place. It's an extravagant 19th-century mansion built by a wealthy Bengali merchant. It's filled with amazing art, sculptures, and furniture from Europe. It feels like stepping into a European palace right in the middle of Kolkata.
place.essential: Here's a pro tip: you can't just walk in here. You have to get a special permit from the government beforehand. It's a bit of a process, but it's worth it to see all the incredible art inside. Just know that you probably won't be able to take photos.
place.story: Built by Raja Rajendra Mullick in 1835, this is one of the best-preserved and most elegant private residences in Kolkata. Its story is one of opulence and art, housing a vast collection of statues, paintings, and curios from around the world. It’s a glimpse into the lavish lifestyle of a bygone era.

place.address: Victoria Memorial Hall, 1, Queens Way, Maidan, Kolkata, West Bengal 700071
place.description: This is probably the most famous landmark in Kolkata. It's a massive, white marble building that looks like a palace. It was built in memory of Queen Victoria. The building and its surrounding gardens are just stunning.
place.essential: Go in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the heat. Wear comfy shoes because the gardens are huge! It’s a great place to just walk around, people-watch, and admire the beautiful building.
place.story: A grand marble monument built in memory of Queen Victoria. Conceived by Lord Curzon, it was designed to be a symbol of the British Empire's might. Today, it stands as a museum and a historical landmark, surrounded by beautiful gardens, telling the story of the British Raj and its impact on India.

place.address: JBS Haldane Ave, Mirania Gardens, East Topsia, Topsia, Kolkata, West Bengal 700046
place.description: If you're traveling with kids or are just a science enthusiast yourself, this is a fun and educational place. It’s packed with interactive exhibits, a cool space theater, and a giant ropeway. You can easily spend an entire day here.
place.essential: If you're traveling with family, this is the place to be. You could easily spend the whole day here because there’s so much to see and do. The interactive exhibits are a blast, and the ropeway is a must!
place.story: A modern hub of science communication and entertainment. Opened in 1997, its story is one of interactive learning and fun, with a Space Odyssey, a Dynamotion Hall, and an interactive science park. It's a place that inspires curiosity in both children and adults.

place.address: 2, Alipore Rd, Alipur Zoological Garden, Alipore, Kolkata, West Bengal 700027
place.description: This is the oldest zoo in India and a great place to see a wide variety of animals. It's a nice escape from the city hustle. They have everything from big cats to birds and reptiles.
place.essential: Heads-up: the zoo is closed on Thursdays. The best time to go is during the cooler winter months. Wear super comfy shoes, because you'll be walking around a lot to see all the different animals!
place.story: One of the oldest zoos in India, opened in 1876. Its story is one of conservation and a sanctuary for wildlife. It's famous for housing the now-extinct Aldabra Giant Tortoise, Adwaita, and continues to be a popular destination for families.

place.address: Ganesh Talkies, 267, Rabindra Sarani, Raja Katra, Singhi Bagan, Jorasanko, Kolkata, West Bengal 700007
place.description: This is where the great poet Rabindranath Tagore was born and raised. It's not just a house; it's a museum dedicated to the Tagore family's legacy. You'll get a real sense of their artistic and intellectual contributions to Bengal.
place.essential: This is a must-see for anyone interested in history. Before you go, double-check their hours; they're usually closed on Mondays. Also, be ready to take off your shoes and pay a small fee for photos.
place.story: The ancestral home of the Tagore family, a dynasty of artists, writers, and reformers. This is where Rabindranath Tagore was born and where he wrote many of his masterpieces. The house is a museum, a living testament to Bengal's cultural renaissance.

place.address: 27, Jawaharlal Nehru Rd, Fire Brigade Head Quarter, New Market Area, Dharmatala, Taltala, Kolkata, West Bengal 700016
place.description: This is India's oldest museum and an absolute treasure trove. It's huge, so you'll need a few hours to explore. They have everything from ancient fossils and Egyptian mummies to rare art and sculptures. It’s a must-visit for history lovers.
place.essential: This museum is massive, so plan to spend at least half a day here. Leave your big bags at the entrance and just bring the essentials. They've got a mummy, which is super cool, but you might need to pay a little extra to take photos.
place.story: The oldest and largest museum in India, founded in 1814. Its story is one of discovery and preservation, with a vast collection of artifacts ranging from ancient sculptures and fossils to a 4,000-year-old Egyptian mummy. It’s a journey through the history of India and the world.

place.address: Maidan, B.B.D. Bagh, Kolkata, West Bengal 700021
place.description: Even if you're not a cricket fan, you should check this place out. It's one of the most iconic cricket stadiums in the world. The atmosphere during a match is electric, but even when it's empty, it's cool to see a place with so much history.
place.essential: You have to experience a cricket match here at least once—the atmosphere is absolutely incredible! If there’s no match, you can still visit the grounds. It's a place with so much history, and you can really feel it.
place.story: A cricket stadium with a rich history and a legendary status. Its story is one of sporting triumphs, epic matches, and a passionate fan base. It has witnessed some of the most memorable moments in cricket history and is often referred to as the "Mecca of Indian cricket."

place.address: Maidan, Fort William, Hastings, Kolkata, West Bengal 700021
place.description: This is an old British fort that's now used by the Indian Army. You can't actually go inside, but you can see it from the outside. It’s a huge, star-shaped structure that gives you a glimpse into the city’s colonial past.
place.essential: This is a military base, so you can't really go inside. The only thing to see is the outside, but it's still cool to get a glimpse of this historic fort that's still in use.
place.story: A massive military fortress built by the British in 1781 after the original fort was destroyed. It’s a story of military strategy and power. Today, it serves as the headquarters of the Indian Army's Eastern Command and is a restricted area, a silent sentinel of the city's colonial past.

place.address: 29, Ashutosh Chowdary Ave, Ballygunge, Kolkata, West Bengal 700019
place.description: A newer temple, but it's gorgeous. It's made of pure white marble, and the carvings are super detailed. It's dedicated to various gods and goddesses, and the evening aarti (prayer) is a beautiful ceremony to watch.
place.essential: Go in the evening to see the temple lit up—it's gorgeous! You'll need to take off your shoes, and you can't take photos inside, so just take a moment to enjoy the beauty of the place.
place.story: A modern temple built by the Birla family, dedicated to Radha and Krishna. Its story is one of devotion and intricate craftsmanship, with the temple constructed from white marble. It's a serene and beautiful space, offering a peaceful retreat from the city's noise.

place.address: Kolkata, West Bengal
place.description: Tucked away in the city center, this is a charming little Anglo-Indian neighborhood with red-brick buildings. It has a unique, old-world vibe. It truly comes alive during Christmas with lights, music, and the smell of delicious cakes. It's a hidden gem.
place.essential: It’s a great little neighborhood to walk through. It's especially magical around Christmas with all the decorations. Just remember that people live here, so be respectful of their privacy. A good camera is a must for all the cool photos you'll want to take!
place.story: A unique, Anglo-Indian residential colony with a distinct red-brick architecture. Built during World War I to house soldiers, it now tells a story of a close-knit community, a blend of cultures, and a vibrant Christmas celebration that is a local legend.

place.places: The Mother Teresa House Of The Missionaries Of Charity
place.category: Memorial / Place of Worship / Charitable Institution
place.address: 54A, Acharya Jagdish Chandra Bose Rd, near Ripon Street, opposite Bamboo Villa, Taltala, Kolkata, West Bengal 700016
place.description: This is the headquarters of Mother Teresa's mission, and it's where she is buried. It's a very humble and peaceful place. You can visit her tomb and see a small museum with her belongings. It's a truly moving experience.
place.essential: This is a very quiet, respectful place. Just go with an open mind and a calm heart. It’s a place for reflection, not sightseeing, so be quiet and dress modestly. There’s no entry fee, of course.
place.story: The former home of Saint Teresa of Calcutta. It's a place of pilgrimage and tells a story of compassion and selfless service. Visitors can see her tomb, a small museum, and her room, which has been preserved as it was when she lived there. It's a symbol of hope and charity.

place.address: Kolkata, West Bengal
place.description: You absolutely can't miss this place if you love books. It's basically a gigantic open-air book market where you can find anything from brand-new bestsellers to rare, decades-old books. It's often called "Boi Para," which means "Book Colony" in Bengali.
place.essential: This is a book lover's paradise! Just be prepared to get a little lost in the sea of books. Bring cash, because most of these amazing street vendors don't take cards. And don't be shy—haggling is a big part of the fun here.
place.story: Known as "Boi Para" or "Book Alley," this street is a paradise for book lovers. Its story is one of intellectual pursuits, with countless bookstalls lining the pavement, selling everything from rare old editions to new releases. It's the heart of Kolkata's literary and academic scene.

place.address: Prinsep Ghat, Ganga access ghat, Kolkata, West Bengal
place.description: It's one of the most romantic spots in the city. There's this beautiful old monument, and you can just sit by the river and watch the boats go by. It’s a great place for a relaxing evening walk or a boat ride, with a fantastic view of the Vidyasagar Setu.
place.essential: If you want the perfect photo, this is the spot. Go early in the morning or just before sunset. It’s so peaceful and romantic. You can take a little boat ride on the river, and the view of the big bridge is amazing from here!
place.story: A picturesque ghat on the banks of the Hooghly River, named after James Prinsep, an Anglo-Indian scholar. With its beautiful Palladian porch, it's a popular spot for a leisurely stroll and offers a breathtaking view of the Vidyasagar Setu (2nd Hooghly Bridge). It's a place where history meets romance.

place.address: Kolkata, West Bengal 711101
place.description: This isn't just a bridge; it's the heart of the city. It's a massive steel structure that connects Kolkata and Howrah. It's incredibly busy with people and vehicles all day long. Seeing it lit up at night is a sight you won't forget.
place.essential: Don't just drive over it—walk it if you can! The views are incredible, especially in the evening. Just be mindful of the huge crowds and the crazy traffic. It's a real slice of Kolkata life.
place.story: An engineering marvel and the city's most iconic landmark. Built without a single nut or bolt, this cantilever bridge connects Howrah and Kolkata. Its story is one of constant motion, carrying millions of people and a testament to the city's relentless energy. It's the lifeline of Kolkata.

place.category: Cathedral / Historic Church / Place of Worship
place.address: Rabindra Sadan, 1A, Cathedral Rd, Maidan, New Market Area, Kolkata, West Bengal 700071
place.description: This is a beautiful old church with stunning Indo-Gothic architecture. The stained-glass windows are beautiful, and the interior is very peaceful. It's a popular spot during the Christmas season and looks amazing at night.
place.essential: It’s a stunning church, and the best time to visit is during Christmas when it's all lit up. Be sure to be quiet inside, as it's an active place of worship. The architecture is really beautiful.
place.story: An elegant Gothic-style cathedral, a landmark of colonial architecture. Consecrated in 1847, its story is one of faith and endurance, having survived several earthquakes. It's a serene place, with beautiful stained-glass windows, and stands as a peaceful oasis in the bustling city.

place.address: PHYSICS BLOCK, BIRLA INDUSTRIAL & TECHNOLOGICAL MUSEUM, 19A, Gurusaday Road Near Ballygunge Ice Skating Rink, 19a, Gurusaday Dutta Rd, Beck Bagan, Ballygunge, Kolkata, West Bengal 700019
place.description: This was the first science museum in India, so it's a pretty big deal. It's a fun place to learn about science and technology through hands-on exhibits. It’s great for both kids and adults.
place.essential: This is a fun and interactive museum, especially for kids. It's a great place to learn while having fun. You might want to get a ticket that includes a few different shows to make the most of your visit.
place.story: Established in 1959, it's the first science museum in India. Its story is one of popularizing science and technology, with its exhibits focusing on various scientific principles and their applications. It's a place that brings science to life.

place.address: 92, Rabindra Sarani, near Nakhuda masjid, Kolutolla, Kolkata, West Bengal 700073
place.description: This is Kolkata's largest and most impressive mosque. It was built to look like a Mughal tomb, and the architecture is just stunning. It can hold thousands of people and is a major center for prayer, especially during festivals.
place.essential: It's a beautiful mosque, so be sure to dress appropriately, covering your head and arms. Remember to take off your shoes before you enter. It's an active place of worship, so be respectful of the people praying, especially during prayer times.
place.story: The largest mosque in Kolkata, built in the early 20th century, inspired by the tomb of Mughal Emperor Akbar at Sikandra. Its story is one of faith and community, serving as a center of worship and a prominent landmark in the Burrabazar area.
